name: Viridi
description: Nurture a small pot of succulents that grow in real time. Viridi is a safe haven, a place you can return to for a moment of peace and quiet whenever you need it.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 2.0 GHZ Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Must support shader model 2.0 DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 200 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Disclaimer: I beta tested this game.   Viridi is exactly what it says on the tin: it's a little virtual garden where you watch your plants grow.  The gameplay itself is minimalistic. Apart from planting your succulents, watering them, and zooming in to sing at them, there's very little else you can do. It's supposed to be a very zen experience — similar to keeping actual plants — so if you expect more interactivity than that then this is not the game for you. I usually had it on in the background while I went on with my day as always (hence my exorbitant playtime), but you don't need to leave it on all the time. Your plants will grow just fine while the game is closed as well, so if you only want to spend 5 minutes a day checking up on your plants, then you can do that too. As you can see the joy of the game doesn't lie within its interactivity, but rather within owning a virtual garden in itself.  While this game does have micro transactions, it's entirely possible to play it without ever spending a single penny on it as you start out with 10 plants and you get a free seedling every week.  I very much enjoy playing this game. It's an extremely niche title, but if this game sounds like your cup of tea, I fully recommend you give it a try. It's free so there's literally no downside to trying it out either.

As in real life you can have your own plants watch them grow, water them, so ... what does make this game different to real life plants?  Well 'Viridi' is a very relaxing 3D garden simulation game, created with Unity engine.  You can plant colorful plants, many species from every parts around the world, watching them grow meanwhile you're listening relaxing music makes this game very relaxing after a stressful day.  Another point is that you can have a lovely snail, which i named Bob, that makes this game mor interesting. You can give a name for every plant, including your pot.  Microtransactions aren't so bad (prices are lower tha other items on market), to get achievements you have to buy more plants (collect them all dammit), but you can get one for free weekly.  If you love plants and snails, you will love this game.  10 / 10

Viridi is a free to play Zen edutainment simulation game, that is relaxing and casual. It is a cross-platform mobile game. It worked on Win 10, looked ok, sounded ok, played ok. You are growing many plants in a big pot of dirt. As much fun as watching Plants grow. You can water and sing to each plant. You can remove weeds. It takes a few days for plants to grow. Log in once a day for a few minutes, check each plant for water and pick weeds out. Game is easy to figure out how to do things with your mouse and arrow keys. Has a background music mute. Press 'z' to toggle the UI control. You can rename plants and snail and give the pot a name.  Has Steam Achievements for maturing and flowering each plant. Has a random plant reward for once a week in the in-game store menu. When you get a new plant you can place it in your garden and remove plants that you have the acheivements for. You can pick up plants and replant them in a different place in your pot. Use the in-game store for info about and size requirement of plant. Check the steam forum of the game for the plant trading thread and other tips.  Try it, maybe you might like it.  For more info:         YouTube™ Video:  Viridi- F2P Review

A charming game about relaxing with a wide variety of adorable plants. No two players will have the same garden, as each plant grows into a variety of colors and flowers. Watching your plants grow is a genuinely rewarding feeling. You even have the option to name your plants-- and your snail friend-- to further personalize the experience. There are microtransactions in the form of exclusive plants, but the prices are extremely reasonable. Nothing priced over 40 cents. For $5 you gain access to a new map, and a second pot to tend to.  I highly encourage anyone who's into soothing little games to give this a download. It's free to play, so you lose nothing if you end up not enjoying it. A win/win!

This game is really simple. Not very game like, there aren't objectives or anything like that. It's very to the point. Plant suculants and keep them from dying. Remove random grass that accumulate in the pot.   The things I find wrong with this game: if you mess a pot up, you can't restart it. Or even have multiple pots. There's no tutorial since its such a simple game, but that resulted in me choosing an initial set up I wasn't too fond of because I thought I could change it. I also accidentally over watered and killed a plant. There are beautiful flowers that sprout, and I'm sure that they don't last long IRL, but I'd like to see them last longer than 15 seconds since this is virtual and not real. What would really make this more enjoyable is multiple pots. I could replant suculants I don't want in the other one and it would add to the difficulty of keeping multiple ones alive. IDK maybe that's in the paid version...  Micropurchaces aren't really a big deal since you earn random seeds each week.   Overall I still find myself logging in every day to see if there are new seeds and remove grass.

Viridi is like a more involved Mountain. In Mountain, you could shake the mountain, and rearrange things in it, along with the chance to destroy the mountian with a few keystrokes.  Viridi is no different. You choose a pot and name it, then you choose your starter set of plants and can rename it, then you notice the adorable snail patrolling on the rim of the pot. You can rename it. It's supposed to be a 'sanctuary' to get away from it all. I'm not sure if you need to be in the game for the plants fo grow, but so far they are little excuses for plants. There's always the option to overwater and kill them, with only one way to get a new game.   As far as features go, there is quite a bit behind a paywall, but this paywall is made of paper because the plants cost dimes.
Viridi is really relaxing and I think the game is super cute. When you're stressed out and tired, Viridi is like a breath of fresh air. Plus there's a cute snail!

This is a very cute, zen game with a wonderful soundtrack. I like to open it every other day or so for a little while to listen to the music, watch my plants grow and snail make his rounds around my pot. How this little game plays is you get a pot and a choice of a few succulents, or seeds and to choose what pot you'd like to plant them in. You can get more succulents by paying for them with extra pennies, or you can wait a week, and you'll get a free one. You then get to watch the little ones grow into fully matured little plants, accompanied by beautiful music and a cute little snail. You water the plants by clicking on them and clicking a little circle icon with a little squirt bottle on it, it's easy to accdently overwater them by mistakenly clicking the icon multible times (That I occasionly do) but the little plants normaly forgive you for making mistakes. Virtual plant simulator that is surprisingly fun. You choose your first flowerpot and seedlings for free, they make money by charging $.09-$.39 for additional seedlings. If you don't want to pay, they'll still reward you with an additional seed once a week. There are additional things you can buy like a 'map to a grove' that seems to indicate you can plant a new pot but I don't understand how the two are connected.   There are no instructions so expect some frustration figuring things out. It feels like a phone game translated poorly to PC. The UI is nondescript and clicking directly on the plant you need to water doesn't work right. Strangest of all, as of the time of this review, there's no way I can see to exit the game other than Alt-tabbing and closing the window via the taskbar.  Still, once you get through the initial aggravation, the game is fun to jump in and out of for a few minutes for some quick weed pulling and watering. Don't miss more than one day or they'll start drooping. You'll get an achievement if you're able to grow your plant to maturity. I do a lot better with this virtual plant than I do with real ones.  One more thing, the snail farts when you pick it up.

At first, I had my doubts, but I played Viridi and was pleasantly surprised.  It's not much, and definitely not an adventure or action game, but Viridi is relaxing and peace inducing.  You water each plant and watch them grow over time. You can move them around a pot of your choice and even name them as well as your free snail.  The music is so very calm and it just melted away my problems in a matter of seconds.  So, it may not be one of the highest rated games, but it's cute and it's free and there's no reason why you shouldn't play it.

Nowhere near as boring as people suggest.  You select a pot. You select a starter-pack of plants. You plant and water them. They start ridiculously tiny. They grow normal size in a few days, and then you simply keep them alive by watering them every day. You could log in every two days once they're full-grown, they're a little more hardy.  IMPORTANT TIP: When you begin, water your plant 1x EACH. NOT MORE! You'll flood them, stunt their growth! You get a free plant every week.  As for the rest, if you buy any other Steam game and have leftover change... plants start at $0.09 USD each. You have $0.55 leftover from a recent game purchase??? This game is perfect to dump it on.  You can also 'sing' to the plants by zooming in on them. This speeds their growth greatly. You can only do this to one plant at a time. So choose your main plant, and leave the game open overnight as you sleep - turn off the music. You can sing to THE SNAIL too. It appreciates it. You can also water the snail... you can FLOOD the snail, and it doesn't care. So if you're bored, you can wet the snail a lot.  I suggest playing another game or surfing the internet while running this game.

Snail? Snail. This game is more than just a stoners dream. This game brings up many theories in many reviews, but here's mine. This is syymbolic of life. You are not able to remove or undo anything (except your pot name or your entire pot). The plants can be moved, but not removed. The snail will stay, unaffected by time, circling the rim endlessly. Plants will grow, as will people. You mil plant new seeds and meet new people. Relationships and plants take patience and care to grow. But no matter what, you can never truly remove a plant from your life. You can move it around, underwater it, overwater it, but the plant will still be there, green or brown, sated or overwatered, dead or alive. People never really leave your life. They may move far enough away that you may never see them again, but they will have a lasting effect on your life and they will be a part of you until you buy a new pot. Viridi has truly shown us the truth.

The camera is a bit restricted, you can't zoom in on any individual thing and the label text is often obscured. Unless you choose to purchase the rather reasonably priced supplementary plants, it is free, so it's a bit hard to complain about a game I paid nothing for occasionally flipping out and leaving your plants shrunken or blown up.

Terrible.  The interface is just bad, and there's not even much for you to interact with, so I don't get how they could get that wrong; I couldn't even find a quit button so I guess the developers wants you to close the game with the X button of its window. I'm using my old dual-core system as a way to test performance in games and this one, cause to Unity, hits it a lot, especially in the garden/woods scene, where there's like just graphics from the 90's to show.  Planting here is just tedious. If you really want to do it, do it in real life, because waiting weeks by staring at the empty soil is way more fun than this, and also will teach you something useful.  You don't even have much to do: you select a vase and a pre-made bundle of plants, then remove the wild weeds, water each plant separately by selecting each one of them and then pressing a button, and that's how it always begins, and also everything you have to do. Come back in a day or 2, rinse and repeat.  The graphics are very basic, so much that my ps1 would laugh at it; the sound effects almost non-existant, and the music forgettable. And if that's not enough for you, you can pay micro-transactions to buy new plants and feed the developers.  Well I'm sorry to be so rude, but I think you should find a job that you are able to do, rather than asking money for one that you aren't.

I really wanted to like this game, because it had good recommendations and the pictures seemed really nice, but honestly... it's incredibly boring. There is about 30 seconds of playtime every day. I haven't watered my plants since yesterday, but it still says they are 'sated' so I can't even water them again, so all I did today was to click on some weeds like three times. I know the plants grow in real time and all, but it could really go a bit faster. I wonder how long it takes to actually have your plants look as beautiful as they are on the picture.

You start out the game by picking whatever pot you want to grow your plants in. I choose the Swiss Concrete because it was the least ugly. Still ugly, just the least ugly. After that you pick the starter plant. You only get 3 options on this one. The Pallidus, Prasinus, or Primus. I picked the Prasinus because it was, yet again, the least ugly. After this you get to name your pot. I named mine 'Green' since Prasinus is Latin for Green. After you name your pot, you get to see your plant as just a yound bunch of grass pieces with a small snail on the outside of your plant. In the bottom right there is a shining gray cirle that upon clicking on pulls up a menu with 4 options. The first on is for muting the sound, the second one assures you that the game isn't actually 'free', the third one lets you place other plants, and the fourth on closes the menu.  The plants grow in real time as I hear, so you might as well just start an irl garden since that would be much more entertaining and healthy. Plus you could get plant seeds cheaper irl.

I can't get it to work on Windows 10 and the developers refuse to cooperate with me. I've reloaded the operating system several times and even had the entire machine sent back to MSI where they reloaded it AGAIN and Viridi still crashes on startup. When I brought this issue to the devs at Icewater in the past they brushed me off and gave me a response along the lines of 'lol idk good luck'. Before I lost complete ability to play altogether I lost all my plants to a bug in the system and got zero reimbursement even though the fault was on their end. I've spent money on this game and have supported it for over a year, so the lack of support for the customer is a //real buzz kill//. Now I can't play it at all, so. There went my original good opinions on it and I'll be telling all my friends with 10 to not even bother. I know that not every game needs to be an action-packed thrillfest. I'm okay with slow, relaxing, low-interaction experiences. However, spritzing a couple of seedlings once a month and trusting just doesn't lead anywhere. If the game is meant to be relaxing, it is stifled by the lack of stimuli. If the game is meant to immerse the player in the steady and unassuming beauty of gardening, then it seriously lacks execution when it comes to what makes gardening therapeutic.  In short, Viridi is just lacking. There's nothing here but some pretty colors and music. Even soothing experiences need some sort of interaction; this is just watching paint dry.

It's pretty. It has nice, calm music. The probelm is, gameplay consists of clicking the mouse about 12 times over a 30 second to 1 minutes period, then you are done. In my opinion, the plants grow too fast and the interactivity is too low.  It would be nice to manually pour the the water, and not have everything so spelled out for you. To trim off dead limbs... Optimally position your plant in a sunny windowsill, rather than have it floating in a colorful void.  So, to summarize: It's pleasant, but I found it shallow and unsatisfying.

This game is charming for about 15 minutes. I love the look and the idea but there isn't enough going on to keep me coming back from day to day as a 'free' user and I end up just forgetting it. There are a lot of little things that add up to a rather disconnected experience. This isn't a problem I've had with other, similar digital plant growing simulators I've owned. Despite it's beautiful aesthetics and style, this very much feels like a freemium mobile game, the kind you'd rather just pay for once to own and play with rather than feel like you're just missing access to most of the game without making lots of little micro payments. This isn't a feeling I like and kills a lot of the charm for me. Especially as a PC game.
